articles.headline: Ukraine’s Uncertainties Include Financial Aid
articles.snippet: In the middle of political unrest, Ukraine’s opposition appears closer to forcing the rejection of agreements with Russia and turning to the West.
articles.abstract: In the middle of political unrest, Ukraine’s opposition appears closer to forcing the rejection of agreements with Russia and turning to the West.
articles.lead_paragraph: KIEV, Ukraine — As Ukraine’s political crisis has deepened, an economic question looms: Will Russia continue to bail out the country if it again tilts to the West?

articles.headline: With Ad Dollars Elusive, Yahoo’s Revenue Falls
articles.snippet: The Internet portal and web publisher said its fourth-quarter revenue was $1.27 billion, down 6 percent from the same quarter a year ago.
articles.abstract: The Internet portal and web publisher said its fourth-quarter revenue was $1.27 billion, down 6 percent from the same quarter a year ago.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Under the turnaround plan devised by Yahoo’s chief executive, Marissa Mayer, the company gained traffic and mobile users in 2013 and introduced a bevy of products, like a slick digital food magazine and a mobile weather app.

articles.headline: Confronting Old Problem May Require a New Deal
articles.snippet: Just as now, some in the 1930s feared that unemployment would remain stubbornly high, permanently; the response 80 years ago was the New Deal.
articles.abstract: Just as now, some in the 1930s feared that unemployment would remain stubbornly high, permanently; the response 80 years ago was the New Deal.
articles.lead_paragraph: We look back upon the Great Depression as a discrete event with a beginning and an end; a long and profound economic shock but one that turned out to be nonetheless temporary. In the 1930s, however, many feared that what John Maynard Keynes clinically called “equilibrium at less than full employment” might, in fact, be the new normal — forever.

articles.headline: An American Family Returns to the Table
articles.snippet: Among the Super Bowl commercials is a sequel to a Cheerios ad that received baldly racist online condemnation for the interracial family at its heart.
articles.abstract: Among the Super Bowl commercials is a sequel to a Cheerios ad that received baldly racist online condemnation for the interracial family at its heart.
articles.lead_paragraph: A brand that garnered brickbats — and bouquets — last year for its take on modern family life is returning with another 30-second parable about diversity, this time during Super Bowl XLVIII, the year’s biggest showcase for advertising.

articles.headline: ‘Fragile Five’ Is the Latest Club of Emerging Nations in Turmoil
articles.snippet: The name identifies Turkey, Brazil, India, South Africa and Indonesia as economies too dependent on skittish foreign investment to finance their growth ambitions.
articles.abstract: The name identifies Turkey, Brazil, India, South Africa and Indonesia as economies too dependent on skittish foreign investment to finance their growth ambitions.
articles.lead_paragraph: The long-running boom in emerging markets came to be identified, if not propped up, by wide acceptance of the term BRICs, shorthand for the fast-growing countries Brazil, Russia, India and China. Recent turmoil in these and similar markets has produced a rival expression: the Fragile Five.

articles.headline: Rebels in Syria Claim Control of Resources
articles.snippet: Islamist rebels and extremists are using oil and gas proceeds to underwrite their fights against one another as well as President Bashar al-Assad, American officials said.
articles.abstract: Islamist rebels and extremists are using oil and gas proceeds to underwrite their fights against one another as well as President Bashar al-Assad, American officials said.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Islamist rebels and extremist groups have seized control of most of Syria’s oil and gas resources, a rare generator of cash in the country’s war-battered economy, and are now using the proceeds to underwrite their fights against one another as well as President Bashar al-Assad, American officials say.
articles.byline: By Ben Hubbard, Clifford Krauss and Eric Schmitt

articles.headline: Outsiders, Not Auto Plant, Battle U.A.W. in Tennessee
articles.snippet: A unionization drive has drawn national attention as business groups worry about organized labor’s efforts to gain its first foothold at a foreign-owned automobile plant in the South.
articles.abstract: A unionization drive has drawn national attention as business groups worry about organized labor’s efforts to gain its first foothold at a foreign-owned automobile plant in the South.
articles.lead_paragraph: CHATTANOOGA, Tenn. — At the Volkswagen plant nestled in Tennessee’s rolling hills, a unionization drive has drawn national attention as business groups worry about organized labor’s efforts to gain its first foothold at a foreign-owned automobile plant in the South. In a region known as anti-union, many view VW’s response as unusual, if not topsy-turvy.

articles.headline: Hardened, Obama Strikes Tough Tone for Modest Agenda
articles.snippet: President Obama’s embrace of executive orders may be the only route available given deep hostility in Congress, but only so much can be delivered if legislation is not passed.
articles.abstract: President Obama’s embrace of executive orders may be the only route available given deep hostility in Congress, but only so much can be delivered if legislation is not passed.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama’s State of the Union address represented a study in scaled-down ambition.

articles.headline: In France, a Battle to Keep Menus Fresh
articles.snippet: France, known as a world capital of gastronomy, is considering a consumer protection law that would require restaurants to designate fresh dishes as homemade.
articles.abstract: France, known as a world capital of gastronomy, is considering a consumer protection law that would require restaurants to designate fresh dishes as homemade.
articles.lead_paragraph: PARIS — Sit down at a cute Parisian bistro and the chances are the onion soup, the paté and the boudin blanc set before you weren’t prepared from fresh ingredients delivered that morning.

articles.headline: Touring States, Obama Pushes Modest Agenda
articles.snippet: President Obama began a two-day, four-state tour to build support for a series of executive actions on wages, retirement and education.
articles.abstract: President Obama began a two-day, four-state tour to build support for a series of executive actions on wages, retirement and education.
articles.lead_paragraph: WEST MIFFLIN, Pa. — As President Obama took to the road on Wednesday to promote an “opportunity agenda” that he vowed to enact with or without Congress, lawmakers began sorting through issues on which they may yet come together during what promises to be a treacherous midterm election year.
